abstract_sentences.1: It has been shown that Chinese poems can be successfully generated by sequence-to-sequence neural models, particularly with the attention mechanism.
abstract_sentences.2: A potential problem of this approach, however, is that neural models can only learn abstract rules, while poem generation is a highly creative process that involves not only rules but also innovations for which pure statistical models are not appropriate in principle.
abstract_sentences.3: This work proposes a memory-augmented neural model for Chinese poem generation, where the neural model and the augmented memory work together to balance the requirements of linguistic accordance and aesthetic innovation, leading to innovative generations that are still rule-compliant.
abstract_sentences.4: In addition, it is found that the memory mechanism provides interesting flexibility that can be used to generate poems with different styles.

body_sentences.8: More importantly, besides such strict regulations, a good quatrain should also read fluently, hold a consistent theme, and express a unique affection.
body_sentences.9: Therefore, poem generation is widely recognized as a very intelligent activity and can be performed only by knowledgeable people with a lot of training.
body_sentences.10: In this paper we are interested in machine poetry generation.
body_sentences.11: Several approaches have been studied by researchers.
body_sentences.12: For example, rule-based methods (Zhou et al., 2010), statistical machine translation (SMT) models (Jiang and Zhou, 2008; He et al., 2012) and neural models (Zhang and Lapata, 2014; Wang et al., 2016a,c).

ous approaches (e.g., rule-based or SMT), the neural model approach tends to generate more fluent poems and some generations are so natural that even professional poets can not tell they are the work of machines (Wang et al., 2016a).
body_sentences.14: In spite of these promising results, neural models suffer from a particular problem in poem generation, a lack of innovation.
body_sentences.15: Due to the statistical nature of neural models, they pay much more attention to high-frequency patterns, whereas they ignore low-frequency ones.
body_sentences.16: In other words, the more regular and common the patterns, the better the neural model is good at learning them and tends to use them more frequently at run-time.
body_sentences.17: This property certainly helps to generate fluent sentences, but it is not always useful: the major value of poetry is not fluency, but the aesthetic innovation that can stimulate some unique feelings.
body_sentences.18: This is particularly true for Chinese quatrains that are highly compact and expressive: it is nearly impossible to find two similar works in the thousands of years of history in this genre, demonstrating the importance of uniqueness or innovation.
body_sentences.19: Ironically, the most important thing, innovation, is largely treated as trivial, if not noise, by present neural models.
body_sentences.20: Actually this problem is shared by all generation models based on statistics (although it is more serious for neural models) and has aroused a long-standing criticism for machine poem generation: it can generate, and sometimes generate well, but the generation tends to be unsurprising and not particularly interesting.
body_sentences.21: More seriously, this problem exists not only in poem generation, but also in all generation tasks that require innovation.
body_sentences.22: This paper tries to solve this extremely challenging problem.
body_sentences.23: We argue that the essential problem is that statistical models are good at learning general rules (usage of regular words and their combinations) but are less capable of remembering special instances that are difficult to cover with general rules.
body_sentences.24: In other words, there is only rule-based reasoning, no instance-based memory.
body_sentences.25: We therefore present a memory-augmented neural model which involves a neural memory so that special instances can be saved and referred to at run-time.
body_sentences.26: This is like a human poet who creates poems by not only referring to common rules and patterns, but also recalls poems that he has read before.
body_sentences.27:
It is hard to say whether this combination of rules and instances produces true innovation
(which often requires real-life motivation rather than simple word reordering), but it indeed offers interesting flexibility to generate new outputs that look creative and are still rule-compliant.
body_sentences.28: Moreover, this flexibility can be used in other ways, e.g., generating poems with different styles.
body_sentences.29: In this paper, we use the memory-augmented neural model to generate flexible and creative Chinese poems.
body_sentences.30: We investigate three scenarios where adding a memory may contribute: the first scenario involves a well trained neural model where we aim to promote innovation by adding a memory, the second scenario involves an over-fitted neural model where we hope the memory can regularize the innovation, and in the third scenario, the memory is used to encourage generation of poems of different styles.
body_sentences.31: 2 Related Work  A multitude of methods have been proposed for automatic poem generation.
body_sentences.32: The first approach is based on rules and/or templates.
body_sentences.33: For example, phrase search (Tosa et al., 2009; Wu et al., 2009), word association norm (Netzer et al., 2009), template search (Oliveira, 2012), genetic search (Zhou et al., 2010), text summarization (Yan et al., 2013).
body_sentences.34: Another approach involves various SMT methods, e.g., (Jiang and Zhou, 2008; He et al., 2012).
body_sentences.35: A disadvantage shared by the above methods is that they are based on the surface forms of words or characters, having no deep understanding of the meaning of a poem.
body_sentences.36: More recently, neural models have been the subject of much attention.
body_sentences.37: A clear advantage of the neural-based methods is that they can ‘discover’ the meaning of words or characters, and can therefore more deeply understand the meaning of a poem.
body_sentences.38: Here we only review studies on Chinese poetry generation that are mostly related to our research.
body_sentences.39: The first study we have found in this direction is the work by Zhang and Lapata (2014), which proposed an RNN-based approach that produces each new line character-by-character using a recurrent neural network (RNN), with all the lines generated already (in the form of a vector) as a contextual input.
body_sentences.40: This model can generate quatrains of reasonable quality.
body_sentences.42: (2016b) proposed a much simpler neural model that treats a poem as an entire character sequence, and poem generation is conducted character-by-character.
body_sentences.43:
This approach can be
easily extended to various genres such as Song Iambics.
body_sentences.44: To avoid theme drift caused by this long-sequence generation, Wang et al.
body_sentences.45: (2016b) utilized the neural attention mechanism (Bahdanau et al., 2014) by which human intention is encoded by an RNN to guide the generation.
body_sentences.46: The same model was used by Wang et al.
body_sentences.48: Yan (2016) proposed a hierarchical RNN model that conducts iterative generation.
body_sentences.50: (2016c) proposed a similar sequence generation model, but with the difference that attention is placed not only on the human input, but also on all the characters that have been generated so far.
body_sentences.51: They also proposed a topic planning scheme to encourage a smooth and consistent theme.
body_sentences.52: All the neural models mentioned above try to generate fluent and meaningful poems, but none of them consider innovation.
body_sentences.53: The memory-augmented neural model proposed in this study intends to address this issue.
body_sentences.54: Our system was built following the model structure and training strategy proposed by Wang et al.
body_sentences.55: (2016a) due to its simplicity and demonstrated quality, but the memory mechanism is general and can be applied to any of the models presented above.
body_sentences.56: The idea of memory argumentation was inspired by the recent advance in neural Turing machine (Graves et al., 2014, 2016) and memory network (Weston et al., 2014).
body_sentences.57: These new models equip neural networks with an external memory that can be accessed and manipulated via some trainable operations.
body_sentences.58: In comparison, the memory in our work plays a simple role of knowledge storage, and the only operation is simple pre-defined READ.
body_sentences.59: In this sense, our model can be regarded as a simplified neural Turing machine that omits training.
body_sentences.60: 3 Memory-augmented neural model  In this section, we first present the idea of memory augmentation, and then describe the model structure and training method.
body_sentences.61: 3.1 Memory augmentation  The idea of memory augmentation is illustrated in Fig.
body_sentences.63: It contains two components, the neural model component on the left, and the memory component on the right.
body_sentences.64:
In this work, the attention-based RNN generation model presented by (Wang et al., 2016a) is used as the neural mod-
el component, although any neural model is suitable.
body_sentences.65: The memory component involves a set of ‘direct’ mappings from input to output, and therefore can be used to memorize some special cases of the generation that can not be represented by the neural model.
body_sentences.66: For poem generation, the memory stores the information regarding which character should be generated in a particular context.
body_sentences.67: The output from the two components are then integrated, leading to a consolidated output.
body_sentences.68: There are several ways to understand the memory-augmented neural model.
body_sentences.69: Firstly, it can be regarded as a way of combining reasoning (neural model) and knowledge (memory).
body_sentences.70: Secondly, it can be regarded as a way of combining rule-based inference (neural model) and instance-based retrieval (memory).
body_sentences.71: Thirdly, it can be regarded as a way of combining predictions from complementary systems, where the neural model is continuous and parameter-shared, while the memory is discrete and contains no parameter sharing.
body_sentences.72: Finally, the memory can be regarded as an effective regularization that constrains and modifies the behavior of the neural model, resulting in generations with desired properties.
body_sentences.73: Note that this memory-augmented neural model is inspired by and related to the memory network proposed by Weston et al.
body_sentences.75: (2016), but we more focus on an accompanying memory that plays the role of assistance and regularization.

body_sentences.99: 3.3 Model Training  In our implementation, only the neural model component is required to be trained.
body_sentences.100: The training algorithm follows the scheme defined in (Wang et al., 2016a), where the cross entropy between the distributions over Chinese characters given by the decoder and the ground truth is used as the objective function.
body_sentences.101: The optimization uses the SGD algorithm together with AdaDelta to adjust the learning rate (Zeiler, 2012).
body_sentences.102: 4 Memory augmentation for Chinese poetry generation  This section describes how the memory mechanism can be used to trade-off between the requirements for rule-compliant generation and aesthetic innovation, and how it can also be used to do more interesting things, for example style transfer.
body_sentences.103: 4.1 Memory for innovative generation  In this section, we describe how the memory mechanism promotes innovation.

body_sentences.131: 4.2 Memory for style transfer  The effect of the memory is easy to control.
body_sentences.132: For example, the complexity of the behavior can be controlled by the memory size, the featured bias can be controlled by memory selection, and the strength of the impact can be controlled by the weighting parameter β.
body_sentences.133: This means that the memory mechanism is very flexible and can be used to produce poems with desired properties.
body_sentences.134: In this work, we use these capabilities to generate poems with different styles.

body_sentences.137: 5 Experiments  This section describes the experiments and results carried out in this paper.
body_sentences.138: Here, The baseline system was a reproduction of the Attention-based system presented in (Wang et al., 2016a).
body_sentences.139:
the model in This system has been shown to be rather flexi-
ble and powerful: it can generate different genres of Chinese poems, and when generating quatrains it has been shown to be able to fool human experts in many cases (Wang et al., 2016a) and the authors had did a thorough comparison with competitive methods mentioned in the related work of this paper.
body_sentences.140: We obtained the database and the source code (in theano), and reproduced their system using Tensorflow from Google2.
body_sentences.141: We didn’t make comparisons with some previous methods such as NNLM, SMT, RNNPG as they had been fully compared in (Wang et al., 2016a) and all of them were much worse than the attention-based system.
body_sentences.142: Another reason was that the experts were not happy to evaluate poems with clearly bad quality.
body_sentences.143: We also reproduced the model in (Wang et al., 2016c) with the help of the first author.
body_sentences.144: However, since their implementation did not involve any restrictions on rhythm and tone, the experts were reluctant to recognize them as good poems.
body_sentences.145: With a larger dataset (e.g., 1 Million poems), it is assumed that the rhythm and tone can be learned and their system would be good in both fluency and rule compliance.
body_sentences.146: It should be also emphasized that the memory approach proposed in this paper is a general technique and is complementary to other efforts such as the planning approach (Wang et al., 2016c) and the recursive approach (Yan, 2016).
body_sentences.147:
Based on the baseline system, we built the memory-augmented model, and conducted two
2https://www.tensorflow.org/
experiments to demonstrate its power.
body_sentences.148: The first is an innovation experiment which employs memory to promote or regularize the generation of innovative poems, and the second is a style-transfer experiment which employs memory to generate flexible poems in different styles.
body_sentences.149: We invited 34 experts to participate in the experiments, and all of them have rich experience not only evaluating poems, but also in writing them.
body_sentences.150: Most of the experts are from prestigious institutes, including Peking university and the Chinese Academy of Social Science (CASS).
body_sentences.152: 5.1 Datasets  The baseline system was built with two customized datasets.
body_sentences.153:
The first dataset is a Chinese po-
em corpus (CPC), which we used in this work to train the embeddings of Chinese characters.
body_sentences.154: Our CPC dataset contains 284,899 traditional Chinese poems in various genres, including Tang quatrains, Song Iambics, Yuan Songs, and Ming and Qing poems.
body_sentences.155: This large quantity of data ensures reliable learning for the semantic content of most Chinese characters.
body_sentences.156: Our second dataset is a Chinese quatrain corpus (CQC) that we have collected from the internet, which consists of 13, 299 5-char quatrains and 65, 560 7-char quatrains.
body_sentences.157: This corpus was used to train the attention-based RNN baseline.
body_sentences.158: We filtered out the poems whose characters are all low-frequency (less than 100 counts in the database).
body_sentences.159: After the filtering, the remaining corpus contains 9,195 5-char quatrains and 49,162 7-char quatrains.
body_sentences.160: We used 9,000 5-char and 49,000 7-char quatrains to train the attention model, and the rest for validation.
body_sentences.161: Another two datasets were created for use in the memory-augmented system.
body_sentences.162: Our first dataset, MEM-I, contains 500 quatrains randomly selected from our CQC corpus.
body_sentences.163: This dataset was used to produce the memory in the innovation experiment; the second dataset, MEM-S, contains 300 quatrains with clear styles, including 100 pastoral, 100 battlefield and 100 romantic quatrains.
body_sentences.164: It was used to generate memory with different styles in the style-transfer experiment.
body_sentences.165: All the datasets will be released online3.
body_sentences.166: 5.2 Evaluation Process  We invited 34 experts to evaluate the quality of the poem generation.
body_sentences.167: In the innovation experiment, the evaluation consisted of a comparison between different systems and configurations in terms of the five metrics.
body_sentences.168: The innovation questions presented the expert with two poems, and asked them to judge which of the poems was better in terms of the five metrics; in the style-transfer experiment, the evaluation was performed by identifying the style of a generated poem.
body_sentences.169: The evaluation was conducted online, with each questionnaire containing 11 questions focusing on innovation and 4 questions concerned with style-transfer.
body_sentences.170:
Each of the style-transfer questions presented the expert with a single poem and asked them to score it between 1 to 5, with a larger score being better, in terms of compliance, aesthetic innovation,
3http://vivi.cslt.org
scenario consistency, and fluency.
body_sentences.171: They were also asked to specify the style of the poem.
body_sentences.172: Using the poems generated by our systems, we generated many different questions of both types, and then created a number of online questionnaires that randomly selected from these questions.
body_sentences.173: This meant that as discussed above, each questionnaire had 11 randomly selected innovation questions, and 4 randomly selected style transfer questions.
body_sentences.174: Each question was only used once, meaning that it was not duplicated on multiple questionnaires, and so each questionnaire was different.
body_sentences.175: Experts could choose to answer multiple questionnaires if they wished, as each one was different.
body_sentences.176: From the 34 experts, we collected 69 completed questionnaires, which equals to 759 innovation questions and 276 style-transfer questions.
body_sentences.177: 5.3 Innovation experiment  This experiment focuses on the contribution of memory for innovative poem generation.
body_sentences.178: We experimented with two configurations: one is with a one-iteration model (C1) and the other is with an overfitted model (C∞).
body_sentences.179: The memory was generated from the 500 quatrains in MEM-I, and the weighting factor was defined empirically as 16 for C1 and 49 for C∞.
body_sentences.180: The topics of the generation were 160 keywords randomly selected from Shixuhanyinge (Liu, 1735).
body_sentences.181: Given a pair of poems generated by two different configurations using the same topic, the experts were asked to choose which one they preferred.
body_sentences.182: The evaluation is therefore pair-wised, and each pair of configurations contains at least 180 evaluations.
body_sentences.183: The results are shown in Table 2, where the preference ratio for each pair of configurations was tested in terms of the 5 metrics.
body_sentences.184: From the first row of Table 2, we observe that the experts have a clear preference for the poems generated by the C1 model, the one that can produce fluent yet uninteresting poems.
body_sentences.185: In particular, the ‘aesthetic innovation’ score for C∞ is not better than C1, which was different from what we expected.
body_sentences.186: Informal offline discussions with the poetry experts found that the experts identified some innovative expression in the C∞ condition, but most of the them was regarded as being nonsense in the opinion of many of the experts.
body_sentences.187:
In comparison to sparking innovation, fluency and being meaningful is more important not only for non-expert readers, but also for professional poet-
s. In other words, only meaningful innovation is regarded as innovation, and irrational innovation is simply treated as junk.
body_sentences.188: From the second and third rows of Table 2, it can be seen that involving memory significantly improves both C1 and C∞, particularly for C∞.
body_sentences.189: For C1, the most substantial improvement is observed in terms of ‘Aesthetic innovation’, which is consistent with our argument that memory can help encourage innovation for this model.
body_sentences.190: For C∞, ‘Fluency’ seems to be the most improved metric.
body_sentences.191: This is also consistent with our argument that involving memory constrains over-innovation for over-fitted models.
body_sentences.192: The last row of Table 2 is an extra experiment that investigates if C∞ is regularized well enough after introducing the memory.
body_sentences.193: It seems that with the regularization, the overfitting problem is largely solved, and the generation is nearly as fluent and consistent as the C1 condition.
body_sentences.194: Interestingly, the score for aesthetic innovation is also significantly improved.
body_sentences.195: Since the regularization is not supposed to boost innovation, this seems confusing at first glance (in comparison to the result on the same metric in the first row), but this is probably because the increased fluency and consistency makes the innovation more appreciated, therefore doubly confirming our argument that true innovation should be reasonable and meaningful.
body_sentences.196: 5.4 Style-transfer experiment  In the second experiment, the memory mechanism is used to generate poems in different styles.
body_sentences.197: We chose three styles: pastoral, battlefield, and romantic.
body_sentences.198: A style-specific memory, which we call style memory, was constructed for each style by the corresponding quatrains in the MEM-S dataset.
body_sentences.199: The system with one-iteration model C1 was used as the baseline.
body_sentences.200: Two sets of topics were used in the experiment, one is general and the other is style-biased.
body_sentences.201:
The experiments then investigate if the memory mechanism can produce a clear style if the topic is general, and can transfer to a
different style if the topic is style-biased already.
body_sentences.202: The experts were asked to specify the style from four options including the three defined above and a ‘unclear style’ option.
body_sentences.203: In addition, the experts were asked to score the poems in terms of compliance, fluency, aesthetic innovation, and scenario consistency, which we can use to check if the style transfer impacts the quality of the poem generation.
body_sentences.204: Note that we did not ask for the theme consistency to be scored in this experiment because the topic words were not presented to the experts, in order to prevent the topic affecting their judgment regarding the style.
body_sentences.205: The score ranges from 1 to 5, with a larger score being better.
body_sentences.206: Table 3 presents the results with the general topics.
body_sentences.207: The numbers show the probabilities that the poems generated by a particular system were labeled as having various styles.
body_sentences.208: Since the topics are unbiased in types, the generation of the baseline system is assumed to be with unclear styles.
body_sentences.209: For other systems, the style of the generation is assumed to be the same as the style of their memories.
body_sentences.210: The results in Table 3 clearly demonstrates these assumptions.
body_sentences.211: The tendency that romantic poems are recognized as pastoral poems is a little surprising.
